description: This course introduces students to the foundation knowledge of biochemistry and molecular biology, including cellular processes and molecular aspects of cells and tissues in the human body, before they embark on the journey of Health Sciences II to get an overview of the human physiological functions. Topics in this course range from introducing the ingredients of life and biomolecules, mechanisms of membrane transport and cellular transport, cellular events leading to energy production, cell cycle and its regulation, overview of cell signaling and its relationship with neurotransmission and drug responses, to basic blood components and the biology of blood cells. Selected topics would be supplemented by case studies to review the relevance of these concepts to medical conditions or their applications.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: describe the roles of biomolecules in cellular processes and how they help to maintain the normal functions of a cell; and recognize the importance of membrane transport, cellular transport and cell signaling to aid in different cellular functions, which serve the functional basis of tissues, organs, and body systems.

title: Foundation Course for Health Sciences I
description: The human body can be studied through its levels of organization, with each level representing different features of life. In particular, the cellular and molecular levels enable us to appreciate how excitable cells such as neurons communicate within the human body by utilizing electrical voltages created by the movement of electrolytes across cell membranes. The generation of these micro- voltages is an important functional basis of various organ systems, such as the nervous system and the cardiovascular system. In physiology, one of the primary ions of electrolytes is the sodium ion, which plays essential roles in determining plasma osmolarity, water balance and even blood pressure. The human body also has an amazing ability to interpret and process both light and sound waves so we can see and hear. In this foundation course, medical students are introduced to various aspects of basic science and organ-specific human physiology essential for an understanding of how the human body functions. They are exposed to important concepts from both the chemical and physical sciences, which they then relate to human cell and organ functions. Selected case studies are also used to aid students in understanding the medical relevance of these concepts.
outcome: By the end of the course, students should be able to: describe general functions of plasma membrane and different cell organelles. describe four physical processes of heat transfer, and relate them to the body and the mechanism of body temperature control. recognize the bioelectrical properties of a neuron and describe different types of ion channels involved in neural conduction. review the general organization of the nervous system and appreciate the importance of homeostatic control system. distinguish electrolytes and non-electrolytes in body fluid and describe briefly how osmolality and selective permeability of cell membrane are important in determining water balance. review the general physiology of cardiovascular system in the control of blood pressure. identify major chemical and physiological buffering systems in the human body.
syllabus: Lecture Topics: The ingredients of life Cell organelles and cell membrane The electrochemical signals of excitable cells Integration of signals and body control: Nervous system Heat, energy and body temperature Flow, pressure and elasticity Body circulation: Cardio-vascular system Water, electrolytes and body fluid compartments Acids and bases Auto-marking exercises or quizzes (topic-specific)
required_readings: Basic Concepts in Biomedical Sciences I, CUHK – CUSTOM, Taylor and Francis (2015) (ISBN: 9781138181939)
recommended_readings: Vander's Human Physiology: The Mechanisms of Body Function. Eric P. Widmaier, Hershel Raff, Kevin T. Strang. (13th Ed.) Mcgraw Hill Education. (ISBN: 978-1-259-08082-1)

description: This is an integrated course covering the structural, physiological and molecular aspects of cells and tissues in the human body. It provides a solid foundation upon which students can embark onto the full-fledged Medical, Nursing, Pharmacy, and Chinese Medicine curricula.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to: 1. know basic biochemistry, molecular biology, and physiology; 2. recognize the structures of the human body and recall their general functions; 3. appreciate the sophisticated structure-function relationship of the human body and the integrated functions of different body parts; and 4. understand the basics of homeostatic control mechanisms that maintain normal body functions and give rise to disease states under derangement.

title: Public Health and Healthcare Ethics
description: This course will introduce undergraduate students to healthcare issues and challenges facing our society in the 21st century. The study of public health and healthcare ethics related themes will include history of modern medicine and public health, current global health issues, professionalism and various approaches to ethical reasoning that enable students to address the moral concerns related to public health and healthcare challenges. The various academic disciplines within the domains of public health will be introduced through case presentations of various global public health issues including infectious diseases, air pollution, healthcare safety, and non-communicable diseases followed by experience sharing by eminent health professionals.
outcome: By the end of this course, student should be able to: describe and articulate current global public health problems and their determinants describe the complexities of issues encountered in healthcare settings and the importance of professionalism apply bioethical principles and theories in analyzing contemporary public health problems demonstrate ethical arguments in a logical and coherent manner
syllabus: An introduction to public health Ethical principles in public health and healthcare – Public health justice Public Health Problem: Infectious disease Ethics: Ethical approaches, decision-making framework, and patients’ autonomy Ethics: Professional ethics- our guide to professional conduct Ethics: Non-maleficence & beneficence – Quality of care & patient safety Hong Kong Health System Public Health Problem: Lifestyles and non-communicable diseases Public Health Problem: Pollution (Case study in environmental problems: the case of air pollution in Hong Kong) Social Determinants of Health The Frontiers of Public Health (Current Challenges & Global Health)

title: Interprofessional Healthcare
components:
Lecture
Project
Seminar
Interactive Tutorial
Visit
description: Students will learn about the healthcare system in Hong Kong and the roles of medical and allied professionals in health care. Students will interview patients from The Alliance of Patients’ Mutual Help Organisation (APMHO) and understand chronic health problems, patient experience of hospital and community care and professionalism. Students from different disciplines are required to work collaboratively in group to complete a reflective digital assignment. They would be divided into groups and arranged to interview health care service user, including individual(s) with chronic health problem or family carers, to share their experiences related to interactions with health professionals in various situations. The group will then have to capture either their positive and/or negative experiences, and present it through the means of digital storytelling (a short video clip that combines multimedia, including images, sound, text or video).
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to:  describe healthcare provision in Hong Kong; describe and differentiate health care provision in hospitals and in the community; describe and differentiate roles of different medical and allied professionals; identify the complexities of issues encountered by patients relating to disease, healthcare settings and provisions; demonstrate professionalism and interprofessional collaboration.
syllabus: Introduction of module, representatives/schools, learning activities and grouping  Fundamentals to patient-centred care, collaborative working & patient interviewing Health care organization in Hong Kong (HA, DH, NGO and patient support groups) - roles, services and multidisciplinary care in Hong Kong Care transition between inpatient setting and community, discharge planning and interdisciplinary approach on high-quality care transition Medicine management services and regulation in the hospital, overview of quality management System of (bio)pharmaceuticals Breadth of Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM) practices training & accreditation service provision and regulation in Hong Kong Training & accreditation, roles and responsibilities in hospital and community, breadth of services and common cases seen by dietician, occupational health, physiotherapist and social worker

title: Public Health
description: This course will introduce undergraduate students to the discipline of public health and life course approach to health as well as research methods. This course has three parts:Part 1 Introduction to Public Health: health indicators, life course approach to health and determinants, social and behavioural health, health promotion, health system and challenges. Part 2 Evidence based approaches to Public Health: hypothesis testing, study design, survey design and data analysis.Part 3 Interview skillsStudents will be able to apply their knowledge and have hands on experience of interview skills with research participants and patients.
outcome: By the end of this course, students should be able to:1.    describe public health domains and social determinants of health2.    understand the scope of public health with illustrated examples in infectious disease, environmental health, non-communicable diseases3.    understand the use of data, research and evidence base in policy making and its complexities4.    work collaboratively on topical public health issues and in presenting in a conference poster presentation5.    critique and give feedback on poster presentations
syllabus: Course Introduction: An introduction to public health- Global health, social determinants and health inequity- Public Health & healthcare system in Hong Kong- Lifestyle and non-communicable diseases- Infectious disease and pandemics- Environmental health- Population and health data- Research, health studies and evidence base- Tutorials & poster presentation
